entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 5 at 3:44AM CST by NWS Bismarck ND
entry.summary:
A low pressure system will bring an area of snow across south central North Dakota through this morning. While most locations are only expected to see 1 to 3 inches of accumulation, localized amounts as high as 4 to 6 inches will be possible. Snow amounts could vary greatly over short distances, and the exact location of the heaviest snow will be difficult to anticipate until it starts falling. Where snow is heaviest, snow-covered roads and poor visibility can be expected.
Be sure to check the latest forecast information and road conditions before heading out on the morning commute.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Morton; Burleigh; Kidder; Stutsman; Grant; Sioux; Emmons; Logan; La Moure; McIntosh; Dickey

cap:parameter.value: LOCALIZED HEAVY SNOW POSSIBLE THROUGH THIS MORNING

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued March 5 at 3:43AM CST until March 5 at 6:00AM CST by NWS Little Rock AR
entry.summary:
FFWLZK
The National Weather Service in Little Rock has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Southeastern Newton County in north central Arkansas... Southwestern Searcy County in north central Arkansas...
* Until 600 AM CST.
* At 343 AM CST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 3 and 7 inches of rain has fallen between Lurton to Richland Creek Campground to Canaan. The expected rainfall rate is 1 to 2 inches in 1 hour. Flash flooding is likely ongoing.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Moore... Witts Spring... Bohannon... Marsena... Imo... Kay... Watts... Ben Hur... Tilly... Lurton... Cowell... Canaan... Deer...
entry.cap:areaDesc: Newton, AR; Searcy, AR

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued March 5 at 2:39AM MST until March 6 at 7:00PM MST by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FOR THE NORTHEAST PLAINS FROM WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH WEDNESDAY EVENING DUE TO GUSTY WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITY...
.Good mixing of stronger southwest winds aloft, combined with very dry and relatively warm conditions will bring several hours of critical fire weather conditions to the Northeast Highlands Wednesday afternoon to early Wednesday evening.
The National Weather Service in Albuquerque has issued a Fire Weather Watch...which is in effect from Wednesday afternoon through Wednesday evening.
* AREA AND TIMING...Northeast Highlands (Zone 123) from Wednesday afternoon through Wednesday evening.
* 20 FOOT WINDS...Southwest to west 20 to 25 mph with occasional gusts to 35 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...9 to 14 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northeast Highlands

cap:parameter.value: FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH WEDNESDAY EVENING

entry.summary: Pockets of dense fog with visibility of 1/4 mile are occurring across the Rio Grande, Southern Edwards Plateau and east of Interstate 35. entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Rhode Island...Connecticut...
Pawcatuck River At Westerly affecting Washington and New London Counties.
For the Pawcatuck River...including Wood River Junction, Westerly... Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Pawcatuck River at Westerly.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, Lowland flooding is anticipated from Hopkinton downriver through Westerly, Stonington and New Stonington. Lowest lying homes along Hiscox Road in Westerly are inundated by floodwaters. Along Route 3, flooding occurs at homes in French Village in Hopkinton. Follow the advice of local officials, and evacuate if asked to do so. Floodwaters may inundate Route 49 by the North Stonington and Stonington town line.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:00 AM EST Tuesday the stage was 7.3 feet. - Bankfull stage is 7.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 3:00 AM EST Tuesday was 7.3 feet. - Forecast...The river will oscillate above flood stage with a maximum value of 8.8 feet Thursday evening. - Flood stage is 7.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 5 at 3:02AM EST by NWS Charleston SC
entry.summary:
Areas of fog will continue to develop early this morning across portions of interior Southeast Georgia into the Hardeeville, Beaufort and Hilton areas in southern South Carolina. The fog will become locally dense at times with visibilities dropping to 1/4 mile or less. The nature of the fog is such that visibilities will vary greatly over short distances with the risk for locally dense fog being the greatest near bodies of water and other low- lying areas such as marshes, swamps and large ditches. Motorists should remain alert for these conditions this morning.
The risk for more widespread dense fog could increase through sunrise and a Dense Fog Advisory could be needed for parts of the area later this morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Candler; Bulloch; Effingham; Tattnall; Evans; Inland Chatham; Inland Jasper; Beaufort; Coastal Jasper

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 4 at 2:51PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Low pressure tracking into the gulf Tuesday will swing a front towards the panhandle. As the front moves over SE AK, precip is likely for much of the panhandle beginning Tuesday night and lasting through Wednesday. The last few days have been clear and cold so the area is set up for snow at the start. At this time, because the expected movement of the front is from west to east, the amounts of snow does not look enough for a significant winter storm.
Confidence is increasing on 24 hour amounts estimated between 4 - 8 across the panhandle; however, amounts are trending towards the lower end of the spread. With southerly winds picking up in lieu of the heaviest snowfall, temperature profiles look to limit substantial (above 6 inches) snowfall for areas that are not the northern panhandle. This is supported in the NBM probabilities of 6 inches or greater trending down with every model run. Latest guidance is suggesting most locations have roughly a 30% chance of achieving 6 or more inches in a 24 hour period.
For snow type, areas along the coast and southern panhandle look to have dry, fluffy snow to start, but as heavier rates move in, snow will quickly become heavy and wet. For areas in the northern panhandle, expect snow to remain light, dry, and possibly accumulate quickly. Elsewhere, snow looks to begin as light and dry and slowly become increasingly wet.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Municipality of Skagway; Haines Borough and Klukwan; Glacier Bay; Eastern Chichagof Island; Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; City and Borough of Sitka; Admiralty Island; City and Borough of Juneau; Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island; Prince of Wales Island; City and Borough of Wrangell; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Annette Island
